newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - April 29.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - April 29.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Tuesday's electronic version of The Wall Street Journal:
* Boeing's quarterly profits rose but results were still below analysts' forecasts, which sent the stock lower.
* A dispute over the original agreement could undo News Corp's planned investment in EchoStar DISH.O to build a satellite-television venture.
* A $19 per share hostile bid from Harnischfeger caused Giddings & Lewis shares to rise, as the company's board met.
* This quarter, the U.S. Treasury plans to pay off $65 bilion of federal debts amid higher tax receipts.
* March new home sales fell 2.5 percent but maintained a strong seasonally adjusted annual rate of 813,000 single-family homes.
* The Supreme Court refused to hear a challenge to a Baltimore law banning cigarette and liquor advertisements on many billboards, in another setback for the tobacco industry.
* Choice Hotels board voted to divide the company into a hotel owner and operator and a separate firm to franchise hotel brands.
* On average, stock picks by money managers lost 0.2 percent in the first quarter compared to a 2.7 percent rise in the S&P 500, a recent study showed.
* Chrysler met United Auto Worker officials to try to resolve an engine plant strike which began 20 days ago.
* Prodigy is seen launching an Internet service in China via a joint venture with a state-controlled company.
* NovaCare is expected to name its president and chief operating officer as CEO.
* The former chief executive of Viacom's Blockbuster Entertainment Group, Bill Fields, agreed to become CEO of Canadian department store Hudson's Bay.
* Marvel announced a proposed reorganization plan which included a merger with Toy Biz but bondholders voiced opposition to the plan.
* Metro-Goldwyn Mayer Inc plans to buy most of Metromedia's entertainment assets for $373 million plus $200 million in assumed debt.

* Heard on the Street: To their dismay, most money managers are finding 1997 a much tougher year than 1996. Not only did the stock market hit a rough patch from March 11 through April 11 but most managers' stock picks are underperforming the market.

* Credit markets: A late, outright purchase of Treasury securities by the Federal Reserve boosted prices, but analysts said many trades sat out the session awaiting today's release of key economic data.
